Direct Translation: From Antequera the Moor rode out,
Poetic Translation: Came the Moor from Antequera,
Riding from that city ancient:

Direct Translation: Letters he carried in his hand,
Poetic Translation: And the letter that he carried
With dark messages was laden,
And the words in blood were written,

Lyrics: Y no por falta de tinta:
Direct Translation: And not for lack of ink.
Poetic Translation: Not for lack of ink thus painted.
And the Moor who clutched them tightly

Direct Translation: Was a hundred and twenty years old;
Poetic Translation: Sixscore years of life had tasted.

Lyrics: Ciento y veinte a?os, y el moro
Direct Translation: A hundred and twenty years, but the Moor
Poetic Translation: He was now one hundred twenty,
But two hundred seemed, and aged,
For his beard was long and thinning;

Direct Translation: Very long, down to his waist.
Poetic Translation: To his waist it fell in grayness,
And his baldness shone in sunlight,
So his head was nearly naked,
Save the cloth in which he wrapped it,

Direct Translation: That was valued at a great price;
Poetic Translation: Worth a price beyond all payment,

Direct Translation: The Moorish lady who made it
Poetic Translation: Woven by a Moorish lady,
By his sweetheart kind and gracious.
And he rode a mare of spirit,

Direct Translation: That was valued at a great price,
Poetic Translation: Finely bred, beyond all payment,
Not for lack of horses ridden;

Direct Translation: For he had enough of these.
Poetic Translation: Many horses filled his stables,

Direct Translation: The head cloth on his head
Poetic Translation: And the tassels on his headcloth
Were of finest silk created.
Seven ambushes they plotted,
But all seven he evaded.
Through the fields of Archidona

Direct Translation: In a loud voice he said:
Poetic Translation: Crying loudly, he declaimed it:
"Moorish King, if you knew something
Of my sad communications,
Then your hair would be disheveled
And your beard in disarrangement."
To the town once called Elvira,

Direct Translation: He arrived at the gate of Elvira [Granada];
Poetic Translation: With his actions this outrageous,
Went he to GrenadaÅfs palace
Where the Moorish King awaited.
He at last had reached the palace,

Direct Translation: He who from the Alhambra came
Poetic Translation: Who from the Alhambra hastened
With two hundred knights of valor,
All his best and most courageous.

Lyrics: Ante el Rey cuando se halla,
Direct Translation: When he found himself before the King,
Poetic Translation: In to see the King he entered,
And he bowed his head to say this:
"God in Heaven keep Your Highness
And Your Lordship grant salvation."
"Peace to you, Old Moor, and welcome.

Direct Translation: For days I have waited for you.
Poetic Translation: You for days I have awaited.

Direct Translation: What news do you bring me, Moor,
Poetic Translation: Of my city, Antequera,
Tell me, Moor, what news is latest?"

Lyrics: ? No te las dar? , buen Rey,
Direct Translation: "I will not give it to you, good King,
Poetic Translation: "My good King, I fear to tell you;

Lyrics: Si no me otorgas la vida.
Direct Translation: If you do not guarantee my life."
Poetic Translation: Swear my life will not be taken."
"Tell me, Moor, and do not fear me.

Direct Translation: And it shall be guaranteed to you."
Poetic Translation: You are safe; my word is sacred."
"King, you know it is not good news;
All my news with grief is tainted,
For the prince, that Don Fernando,
Antequera has blockaded.
"Many knights are sworn to serve him;
Every day the battle rages.
With them rides Juan de Valasco

Lyrics: Y el que Enriquez se dec?a,
Direct Translation: And he that is called Enriquez,
Poetic Translation: And Enriquez, who is famous,
"He from Rojas and Narvaez,
Knights stouthearted, strong, and brazen.
They attack by day and nightly

Direct Translation: At night, they dig beneath our fortifications.
Poetic Translation: Dig beneath the wallsÅf foundations.
"All the Moors inside were eating
Leather to avoid starvation.

Direct Translation: If you do not help her, King,
Poetic Translation: If, O King, you do not help her,
Then your city will be taken."
Carol Anne Perry Lagemann
